The ability to beautifully and accurately write mathematical expressions is crucial to many fields, particularly in scientific research. Luckily, R Markdown provides an excellent platform for doing this, thanks to its compatibility with LaTeX, a popular typesetting system renowned for high-quality typesetting of mathematical and scientific content.

# Mathematical Formulas

To write mathematical formulas in R Markdown, we use LaTeX syntax. This is enclosed in dollar signs (`$`) for [inline formulas]{style="color:red;"} and double dollar signs (`$$`) for [display formulas]{style="color:red;"}[^1].

[^1]: https://www.cnblogs.com/nowgood/p/latexstart.html#\_nav_4

## Inline mathematical

The formula for the area of a circle is `$A = \pi r^2$`.

And it will render as:

> $$A = \pi r^2$$

## Display Formula

The formula for the area of a circle is:

``` latex
$$
A = \pi r^2
$$
```

Which will render as:

> $$A = \pi r^2$$

## Examples

1.  *Fraction*:

``` latex
$$
\begin{align*}
\frac{a}{b}
\end{align*}
$$
```

renders as:

> $$
> \begin{align*}
> \frac{a}{b}
> \end{align*}
> $$

2.  *Exponents and Subscripts*:

we use `^` for superscripts (exponents) and `_`for subscripts.

``` latex
$$
\begin{align*}
a^{b}\\
c_{d}
\end{align*}
$$
```

renders as:

> $$
> \begin{align*}
> a^{b}\\
> c_{d}
> \end{align*}
> $$

3.  *Roots and Logarithms*:

``` latex
$$
\begin{align*}
Square\ root: \sqrt{a}\\
nth\ root: \sqrt[n]{b}\\
natural\ log: \ln{c}\\
log\ base\ n: \log_{n}{d}
\end{align*}
$$
```

renders as:

> $$
> \begin{align*}
> Square\ root: \sqrt{a}\\
> nth\ root: \sqrt[n]{b}\\
> natural\ log: \ln{c}\\
> log\ base\ n: \log_{n}{d}
> \end{align*}
> $$

4.  *Quadratic equation*:

``` latex
$$
\begin{align*}
x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}
\end{align*}
$$
```

renders as:

> $$
> \begin{align*}
> x = \frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2 - 4ac}}{2a}
> \end{align*}
> $$

5.  *Summation*:

``` latex
$$
\begin{align*}
\sum_{i=1}^{n} i = \frac{n*(n + 1)}{2}
\end{align*}
$$
```

renders as:

> $$
> \begin{align*}
> \sum_{i=1}^{n} i = \frac{n*(n + 1)}{2}
> \end{align*}
> $$

6.  *Integral*:

``` latex
$$
\begin{align*}
\int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-x} dx = 1\\
\int_{a}^{b} f(x) \, dx
\end{align*}
$$
```

renders as:

> $$
> \begin{align*}
> \int_{0}^{\infty} e^{-x} dx = 1\\
> \int_{a}^{b} f(x) \, dx
> \end{align*}
> $$

7.  *Matrix representation*:

``` latex
$$
\begin{align*}
\begin{bmatrix}
a & b \\
c & d 
\end{bmatrix}
\end{align*}
$$

$$
\begin{pmatrix}
a & b \\
c & d 
\end{pmatrix}
$$
```

Renders as:

> $$
> \begin{align*}
> \begin{bmatrix}
> a & b \\
> c & d 
> \end{bmatrix}
> \end{align*}
> $$ $$
> \begin{align*}
> \begin{pmatrix}
> a & b \\
> c & d 
> \end{pmatrix}
> \end{align*}
> $$

8.  *Trigonometric functions*:

``` latex
$$
\begin{align*}
Sine: \sin(x)\\ 
Cosine: \cos(x)\\ 
Tangent: \tan(x)\\ 
Cotangent: \cot(x)\\ 
Secant: \sec(x)\\ 
Cosecant: \csc(x) \\ 
Degree: 30^\circ
\end{align*}
$$
```

renders as:

> $$
> \begin{align*}
> Sine: \sin(x)\\ 
> Cosine: \cos(x)\\ 
> Tangent: \tan(x)\\ 
> Cotangent: \cot(x)\\ 
> Secant: \sec(x)\\ 
> Cosecant: \csc(x) \\ 
> Degree: 30^\circ
> \end{align*}
> $$

9.  *Inverse trigonometric functions*:

``` latex
$$
\\begin{flalign}
Inverse\ sine (arcsine): \arcsin(x) &\\
Inverse\ cosine (arccosine): \arccos(x) &\\
Inverse\ tangent (arctangent): \arctan(x) &
\end{flalign}
$$
```

render as:

> $$
> \small
> \begin{flalign*}
> \text{Inverse sine (arcsine):} \quad & \arcsin(x) &\\
> \text{Inverse cosine (arccosine):} \quad & \arccos(x) &\\
> \text{Inverse tangent (arctangent):} \quad & \arctan(x) &
> \end{flalign*}
> \small
> $$
